articles.title: Research links record temperatures to human-caused climate change
articles.author: George Lee
articles.summary: Summer 2025 was the warmest summer in Ireland ever. The average combined daily day time and night time temperature was 16.19 degrees Celsius. This broke a 30-year-old summertime temperature record of 16.11 degrees set back in 1995. This year's record night time temperatures were made 40 times more likely by human-caused climate change.

articles.title: At UN, Trump attacks climate change efforts in front of leaders of drowning nations
articles.author: MELINA WALLING
articles.summary: Trump has long been a critic of climate science and polices aimed at helping the world transition to green energies like wind and solar. His speech Tuesday was one of his most expansive to date. It included false statements and making connections between things that are not connected. Solar and wind are now 'almost always' the least expensive and fastest options for new electricity generation, according to a July report from the United Nations.

articles.title: At UN, Trump attacks climate change efforts in front of leaders of drowning nations
articles.author: MELINA WALLING
articles.summary: Trump has long been a critic of climate science and polices aimed at helping the world transition to green energies like wind and solar. His speech Tuesday was one of his most expansive to date. It included false statements and making connections between things that are not connected. Solar and wind are now 'almost always' the least expensive and fastest options for new electricity generation, according to a July report from the United Nations.

articles.title: At UN, Trump attacks climate change efforts in front of leaders of drowning nations
articles.author: MELINA WALLING
articles.summary: Trump has long been a critic of climate science and polices aimed at helping the world transition to green energies like wind and solar. His speech Tuesday was one of his most expansive to date and included false statements and connections between things that are not connected. The three cheapest electricity sources globally last year were onshore wind, solar panels and new hydropower.

articles.title: 'Green scam': At UN, watched by drowning nations' leaders, Trump assails the ethos of climate change
articles.author: MELINA WALLING
articles.summary: Trump has long been a critic of climate science and polices aimed at helping the world transition to green energies like wind and solar. His speech Tuesday was one of his most expansive to date. He called renewable energy a 'joke' and 'pathetic' falsely claiming they don't work, are expensive and weak.

articles.title: WATCH: Carter Co. leaders discuss Hurricane Helene's impact & recovery one year after storm
articles.author: Faith Little
articles.summary: It's been one year since Hurricane Helene impacted communities across the region. Carter County Mayor Patty Woodby and Road Superintendent Shannon Burchett discussed recovery efforts in their area on Monday. The full interview is available on News Channel 11's website and can be viewed above.

articles.title: ‘Green scam': At UN, watched by drowning nations' leaders, Trump assails the ethos of climate change
articles.summary: Donald Trump's speech at the United Nations General Assembly didn't match the world many world leaders are contending with. Some countries' leaders are watching rising seas threaten to swallow their homes. Others are watching their citizens die in floods, hurricanes and heat waves exacerbated by climate change.

articles.title: Trump Refers to Climate Change as ‘The Biggest Scam Ever'
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump spoke at the UN General Assembly in New York on Tuesday (Wednesday AEST). He dismissed previous predictions about climate change leading to global catastrophe. The vast majority of climate scientists have concluded that climate change is happening and is mainly caused by fossil fuel pollution. Trump also claimed green energy policies allow countries without restrictions to make money.

articles.title: Bat Cave one year after Helene: People still struggling, determined to rebuild
articles.author: Amber Lake
articles.summary: It's been one year since Hurricane Helene hit Bat Cave in Henderson County, North Carolina. Roads were washed away, homes destroyed, and families stranded. Fire Chief Steve Freeman believes Bat Cave will rebuild, even if it takes time. Samantha Smith needs help from outside community.

articles.title: The Easy Hack That Finally Makes Smoked Wings Crispy
articles.author: Jim Hoffman
articles.summary: In recent years, smoked wings have been making their way onto menus and backyard grills. The low-and-slow method adds irresistible wood-fired flavor, but the skin often comes out soft and rubbery instead of crisp. Baking powder changes the chemistry of the skin and speeds up the Maillard reaction, which creates the browning process.

articles.title: Pacific leaders urge Turkiye to "clear the way" for COP 31
articles.author: Agnes  Tupou
articles.summary: Turkiye and Australia are in a stand-off over hosting rights for next year's COP 31 conference. Pacific countries have written to Turkiye to "clear the way" for the meeting to be brought to the region. Palau's president Surangel Whipps Junior is among Pacific leaders lobbying for the event to be held in Adelaide.

articles.title: Trump tells UN that climate change is a 'con job'
articles.summary: Donald Trump has called climate change the 'greatest con job' according to the UN. He also called it 'unfair' and 'unjustified' in his speech to the United Nations' General Assembly. He said it was a 'con job'.

articles.title: Climate change and health insurance: Impact that must be addressed
articles.author: Nasdaq Globe Newswire
articles.summary: Climate change is the reason behind health issues like respiratory problems and vector-borne diseases. Here is how it works and why it is bad for people's health. It is also bad for the environment and the environment's ability to cope with climate change-related issues.

articles.title: Australians are moving to Tasmania to escape climate change, but the island state is not immune
articles.author: Sophie Jaggers
articles.summary: Jack Taylor and his partner Anna Graham moved from the Sunshine Coast to southern Tasmania last month to escape the heat. National Climate Risk Assessment highlights key climate hazards for the state, including worsening heatwaves, drought and flooding. Dr Karen Palmer, a sea level scientist with the University of Tasmania, says there's "no escaping" the impacts of a warming climate.

articles.title: Climate Defenders Blast Trump's 'Reckless' UN Speech
articles.author: Julia Conley
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump gave a speech to the UN General Assembly on Tuesday. UN Secretary-General António Guterres had warned that the world has entered an age of "reckless disruption and relentless human suffering" and that a shift from fossil fuels to renewable energy is needed to avoid the worst impacts of climate change. 350.org's Namrata Chowdhary and JL Andrepont are critical of Trump's speech.

articles.title: SPAIN VALENCIA FLOODS PROTEST
articles.author: jrp LB
articles.summary: DANA's Victims Association demonstrate asking for Carlos Mazon's resignation as Valencia's regional president. Floods triggered by the DANA weather phenomenon hit the east of Spain on 29 October 2024, devastating Valencia and neighbouring provinces and leaving over 229 people dead. DANA is high-altitude isolated depression weather phenomenon.

articles.title: Climate scientists target Albanese as Turkey holds out on COP talks
articles.author: Nick O'Malley
articles.summary: 60 scientists and researchers signed a letter of protest to Prime Minister Anthony Albanese. They claim the government's new emissions reduction target does not meet the urgency of the crisis outlined in its own risk assessment or its commitment under the Paris Agreement. The letter comes as Albanese and Chris Bowen are trying to break a deadlock with Turkey over hosting rights for next year's UN climate talks.

articles.title: Bob Brown: What ‘the biggest herd of mammals' can do to save the planet
articles.author: Greg Callaghan
articles.summary: Bob Brown has been an environmental activist since the 1970s when he was a GP in Launceston, Tasmania. He was jailed for 19 days in Risdon Prison in 1978 for campaigning against the construction of the Franklin Dam in Tasmania. His new book, Defiance, is an impassioned call to action for those who are feeling depressed or defeated by the challenges facing the world.

articles.title: When does daylight saving start in Australia? Here's everything you need to know
articles.summary: Daylight saving starts at 2am on Sunday, October 5. Clocks will move forward by one hour. Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australia bow out of daylight saving. Norfolk Island, Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands do not.

articles.title: Scientists Predict Extreme Global Water Shortages by 2100
articles.author: Gizmodo
articles.summary: Climate change could leave 74% of the world's drought-prone regions at high risk of severe and prolonged droughts by the end of the century, according to new research from the University of California.       .   ...

articles.title: Trump bashes ‘con job' climate change during his UN speech and says ‘stupid people' have cost countries by buying in
articles.author: Kelly Rissman
articles.summary: President Donald Trump called climate change a 'con job' in his speech to the United Nations General Assembly. He also called 'carbon footprint' a 'hoax' and warned that if countries don't get away from the green scam, they will fail. Many studies show that climate change is a real threat.

articles.title: EPA CEO rallies global support for Africa's climate challenge at Harvard University
articles.summary: Prof. Nana Ama Brown Klutse is the Chief Executive Officer of Ghana's Environmental Protection Authority. She spoke at the Harvard Climate Symposium in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The symposium was the centerpiece of Harvard Climate Action Week, hosted by the Salata Institute for Climate and Sustainability. The week-long event brought together policymakers, academics, business leaders, and non-profit voices to discuss cutting emissions, advancing de-carbonization, and bolstering resilience against climate shocks. Massachusetts Governor Maura T. Healey delivered the keynote.

articles.title: Trump calls climate change policy ‘greatest con-job ever perpetrated', faults it for West's decline
articles.author: Ryan King
articles.summary: President Trump called climate change policies 'the greatest con-job ever perpetrated on the world' in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly. Trump has long been an ardent skeptic of green energy policies. He has championed fossil fuels and nuclear energy. Trump is the president of the United States, but he worries about Europe.

articles.title: Midweek fog, weekend warmth across Minnesota
articles.author: Meteorologist Sven Sundgaard
articles.summary: Another foggy night is likely tonight, but above normal temps and dry weather persist. Warm temperatures are expected to continue into the weekend. The IPCC has warned that Earth is "firmly on track toward an unlivable world" and greenhouse gas emissions must be halved by 2030 to limit warming to 1.5C.

articles.title: Hurricane Narda forms in the Pacific off the west coast of Mexico
articles.author: Upworthy
articles.summary: Hurricane Narda forms in the Pacific off the west coast of Mexico. It has been upgraded to a hurricane as it strengthens off Mexico's west coast and is moving north-northwesterly at 10 km/h. It is expected to strengthen further.

articles.title: Our Rivers Are Suffering From Surging Heat Waves
articles.author: Arden Dier
articles.summary: America's rivers are heating up at a record pace due to human-driven climate change. The average river now experiences nearly two more heat wave events per year than it did in 1980. Cold-water species that require cold water are now facing about 12 additional days of heat stress annually.

articles.title: "Greatest con job": Trump pushes climate change denial in United Nations speech
articles.author: Josephine Walker
articles.summary: President Trump called climate change the "greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world" in remarks at the UN General Assembly on Tuesday. Many of the U.S.'s allies have pledged to combat the trend of global warming. Trump has repeatedly attacked broader global climate initiatives since returning to office in January.

articles.title: Trump upbraids U.N. in speech, claiming ‘your countries are going to hell'
articles.author: The Washington Post
articles.summary: Trump blasted the U.N. for its focus on migration and climate change. He called global warming a 'con job' and said it's a problem for the rich world.  He also called the UN's focus on climate change a "con job."

articles.title: Trump Calls Climate Change 'Con Job' and 'Scam' in UN Speech
articles.author: Solcyré Burga
articles.summary: President Trump called climate change the 'greatest con job ever perpetuated' and a 'scam' during his address at the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday. He warned other countries against enacting green policies. Trump's remarks follow a pattern of attempts by his administration to diminish the threat of climate change.

articles.title: 'Climate change a con job': Trump 'exposes' green energy lies, calls carbon footprint ‘hoax' at UNGA
articles.author: Et Online
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump delivered a fiery address at the United Nations General Assembly on September 23. Trump dismissed climate change as 'the greatest con job ever perpetrated on the world' and labeled the concept of a carbon footprint a 'hoax made up by people with evil intentions.'

articles.title: The 'Climate Change' Danger
articles.author: Lew
articles.summary: There is a constant barrage of propaganda about 'climate change' and 'global warming' from the Left. Alex Epstein is a philosopher and an energy economist. In his book Fossil Future, he argues that modern civilization depends on fossil fuels and that we need to spread them to impoverished parts of the world.

articles.title: Trump calls climate change the 'greatest con job'
articles.summary: Donald Trump dismissed climate change as "the greatest con job" in the world during his address to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday. He also criticised the European Union for reducing its carbon footprint. His administration is carrying out an "energy dominance" agenda that focuses on producing and exporting oil, gas and coal, as well as nuclear.

articles.title: Unprecedented Rains Devastate Marathwada: Villages Marooned and Crops Damaged
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Marathwada region of Maharashtra is experiencing an unexpected deluge. At least eight people have died and over 33,000 hectares of crops have been damaged. Public infrastructure has also taken a hit, as roads and schools were damaged and several small dams compromised. The state government has initiated relief efforts.

articles.title: Trump calls climate change the 'greatest con job'
articles.summary: President Donald Trump is talking to the United Nations General Assembly. He criticises the European Union for reducing its carbon footprint. He also criticises them for making the most of the most important things in the world. He points to the greatest of the greatest, the most significant and the most effective things.

articles.title: Hurricane Narda has formed in the Pacific. In the Atlantic, Gabrielle spurs hurricane watch
articles.author: The Sun Chronicle
articles.summary: Narda has been upgraded to a hurricane. Narda is in the Pacific Ocean off the west coast of Mexico, the National Hurricane Center said Tuesday.       .   in the Atlantic Ocean off Mexico's west coast, the NHC said.

articles.title: Kenya records 255 deaths from rising human-wildlife conflict in 2 years
articles.author: Yan Yujing Bedah Mengo
articles.summary: Kenya has recorded 26,641 human-wildlife conflict incidents over the past two years, resulting in 255 deaths. There were also 725 people injured, 9,300 farm raids, 5,200 livestock predation cases, over 1,000 incidents of property damage and nearly 10,000 direct threats. Kenya Wildlife Service is implementing strategies to curb the conflict.

articles.title: Climate Change May Have Killed 16,469 People in Europe This Summer
articles.author: Who What Why
articles.summary: Climate change caused 16,469 deaths in European cities this summer. This summer was the fourth hottest in European history. Spain experienced its most intense heat wave in history in August 2025. Turkey saw its highest heat wave this summer, which could have tripled the death toll.

articles.title: Narda has strengthened into a hurricane in the Pacific Ocean off the west coast of ...
articles.author: Citrus County Chronicle
articles.summary: Narda has strengthened into a hurricane in the Pacific Ocean off the west coast of Mexico, forecasters say. It is now a Category 4 hurricane.    - The National Hurricane Center has upgraded Narda's strength to a Category 5 hurricane.

articles.title: NDMA Monitors Flood Relief: Pakistan Updates & Aid Efforts
articles.summary: Floods in Pakistan have devastated agricultural lands and caused billions in damages. Climate change is intensifying the monsoon season, glacial melt in the Himalayas and Karakoram ranges is accelerating, increasing river flows but threatening long-term water availability. Rapid urbanization and unsustainable agricultural practices are exacerbating the problem, increasing runoff and reducing groundwater recharge. Pakistan's water storage capacity is critically low, estimated at only around 9% of annual river flows.

articles.title: Europe had over 62,700 heat-related deaths in 2024, report finds
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: More than 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer. Italy was the country with the most heat deaths last summer with an estimated 19,000. Spain and Germany had over 6,000 heat deaths each.

articles.title: Record hot temps killed over 60,000 across Europe in 2024
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: More than 4,400 people died in the UK due to record-breaking hot weather over the three previous summers, according to new research from Stephen Beech's research.       .   i   in the last three summers.

articles.summary: More than 4,400 people died in the UK due to record-breaking hot weather over the three previous summers, according to new research from Stephen Beech's research.       .   i   in the last three summers.

articles.title: Mix of sunshine and rain predicted in Goose Fair weather forecast
articles.summary: Goose Fair opens on Friday, 26th September at 4pm. The weather is expected to be mostly sunny with a high of 18C and a low of 11C. There is a 50% chance of rain between 2pm and 5pm on Saturday. The full forecast for the duration of the fair is not yet available.

articles.title: Spain Records Hottest Summer
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: This summer was the hottest on record for the southern European nation. The Mediterranean region is heating up 20% faster than the global average. The highest single-day temperature of 45.8 C was recorded in Jerez de la Frontera, southern Spain, on August 17.

articles.title: Trump tells UN that climate change is a 'con job'
articles.author: Valerie Volcovici
articles.summary: Donald Trump dismissed climate change as 'the greatest con job' in the world during his address to the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday. He criticized the European Union for reducing its carbon footprint and warned countries that have invested heavily in renewable energy that their economies will suffer. He touted his administration's focus on producing more fossil fuels.

articles.title: A year after Tropical Storm Helene seen in before and after photos
articles.summary: Communities continue to recover from damage sustained by Tropical Storm Helene since 2024, according to Ken Ruinard.      Â   - Ken Rubert.  - Kenneth Ruinard  - KenRubert  -

articles.title: Coalition MPs say Australia's emissions are a fraction of the world's total. What kind of argument is that?
articles.author: Graham Readfearn
articles.summary: Some conservatives argue that Australia's greenhouse gas emissions should not be reduced to net zero because they are a small percentage of the global total. The argument is flawed for a number of reasons. Under the Paris climate agreement, countries must come up with their own pledges to meet a global goal of keeping global heating 'well below 2C' and aim for 1.5C.

articles.title: Narda has strengthened into a hurricane in the Pacific Ocean off the west coast of Mexico, forecasters say
articles.summary: Narda has strengthened into a hurricane in the Pacific Ocean off the west coast of Mexico, forecasters say. Narda is now a Category 4 hurricane, according to the Miami-based National Weather Service.       .

articles.title: Narda has strengthened into a hurricane in the Pacific Ocean off the west coast of Mexico, forecasters say
articles.summary: Narda has strengthened into a hurricane in the Pacific Ocean off the west coast of Mexico, forecasters say. Narda is now a Category 4 hurricane, forecaster say. It is moving west-northwestward at about 10 mph and is expected to strengthen further.

articles.title: The alarming rise in ocean temperatures
articles.summary: 90% of global warming is occurring in the ocean. Global ocean surface temperatures began breaking daily records in mid‑March 2023. The temperature rise could have catastrophic effects for marine life and extreme weather events. Click through the gallery to learn more about rising ocean temperatures and their devastating consequences.

articles.title: Farmland birds in severe decline and sharp drop in seabird numbers, figures show
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: Upland birds have declined by 11% in the long term. Peregrine falcons and whinchats are struggling. There has been no or little change across the UK in the past five years, but there have been falls of 6% in England.

articles.title: Farmland birds in severe decline and sharp drop in seabird numbers, figures show
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: Conservationists warn that British birds are being 'pushed past their limits' as official figures show ongoing declines in species in all habitats. Seabird populations across the UK have seen a sharp drop in numbers in the past five years of around 15%. Woodland birds have seen populations fall by around a third (32%) over the long term. Upland birds have declined by 11%.

articles.title: ‘A disaster': Gatwick expansion is real threat to environment
articles.author: insidecroydon
articles.summary: Croydon's duopoly politicians are in full support of the airport expansion at Gatwick. The second runway will create 14,000 jobs and boost the economy of south-east England. The increase in air traffic will increase the nation's carbon emissions. Green Party leader Zack Polanski describes the decision as a disaster.

articles.title: Pakistan Floods Cause Economic Fallout Amid Global Concerns
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Unprecedented floods have devastated rural and industrial regions in Pakistan, accumulating billions in damages. Geopolitical tensions are simmering across Europe and Asia. Nuclear treaty discussions between the U.S. and Russia remain uncertain. In the South China Sea, maritime disputes intensify as top diplomats voice their concerns over Taiwan's safety.

articles.title: Frosts expected in Kyrgyzstan: Fruit and vegetable harvests at risk
articles.author: Turdubek AIGYROV
articles.summary: The Ministry of Emergency Situations of Kyrgyzstan warns of an upcoming cold snap. The air temperature will drop to 0 to −2 degrees Celsius overnight and in the morning of September 24-25 in agricultural areas of Issyk-Kul and Naryn regions. The ministry reminds farmers to protect their produce by storing it in warm areas and harvesting it after the frost has passed.

articles.title: ‘Who let this guy out on the world stage?': Chris Bowen slammed for climate hysteria at UN
articles.summary: Danica De Giorgio criticises Chris Bowen for his climate hysteria at the UN in New York. Australia emits just one per cent of greenhouse gas emissions. Australia has a 2035 emission reductions target of 62-70 per cent, but it's not clear how much it will cost.

articles.title: Record-breaking heat linked to over 62,000 deaths in Europe last year
articles.summary: There were 62,775 heat-related deaths in Europe between 1 June and 30 September, 2024. The summer of 2024 was Europe's hottest on record, according to the European Union's Copernicus Climate Service. Italy had the highest number of heat deaths, followed by Spain, Germany, Greece, Bulgaria, Serbia, France, Poland and Hungary. Greece witnessed the highest mortality incidence. Greece recorded 373 deaths per million in 2023. Europe is warming at twice the global average.

articles.title: Tools And Butchery Suggest Human Ancestors Reached India 2.95 Million Years Ago
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: Before the start of the Ice Age, monsoon rains shifted northwards, allowing prehistoric hominins to migrate out of Africa, crossing the Kazakh Steppe and the Hindu Kush and reaching northern India almost 3 million years ago. According to the theory presented by the author, a period of global warming may have led to a northward shift of the monsoon.

articles.title: VIDEO: Caribbean SIDS Face $32B Storm Losses: Antigua PM Calls for Bold Climate Action
articles.summary: Antigua and Barbuda's Prime Minister says the Caribbean's next 'win' lies in decisive climate leadership. Antigua has suffered $32 billion in storm damage since 2000. Our What's App Group offers fully customizable and flexible digital marketing packages.

articles.title: China urges joint response to climate change, promoting green, low-carbon transition
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: China urges a joint response to combat climate change and promote green and low-carbon transition. Foreign Ministry spokesman Guo Jiakun made the remarks in response to an inquiry asking when Beijing will release its nationally determined contributions to combat the climate change. Guo was responding to a question from the media.

articles.title: Uganda: Kabarole Farmers Embrace Modern Farming Practices to Mitigate Climate Change Effects
articles.author: All Africa
articles.summary: Farmers in Kabarole District are embracing modern farming practices to fight the growing impacts of climate change in the Rwenzori highlands, which is located along the scenic Rwenzorh mountains.       .   in this article.

articles.title: Uganda: Climate Change Experts Call for Collective Action As Boda-Boda Union Embraces E-Motorcycles
articles.author: All Africa
articles.summary: Climate change experts urge Ugandans to take urgent action in tackling the growing climate crisis. They warn that the country faces dire consequences if collective responsibility is not embraced, if the country does not take action to tackle climate change.      Â

articles.title: Trump Connects Tylenol to Autism; Kimmel Provides Insights on Autism Awareness
articles.author: Dr. Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: Tangier Island, Virginia is at high risk of being submerged within the next 50 years due to erosion and rising sea levels. A seawall was built in 1990 and a breakwater will be built in 2020. Senator Tim Kaine has secured funding for resilience strategies like seawalls and using dredged material.

articles.title: Poor climate crisis warnings put countries around globe at increasing risk of acute hunger
articles.author: Nick Ferris
articles.summary: There is a serious lack of effective early warning systems, according to Chatham House research. Food security is not being factored into these systems, posing a major threat to vulnerable communities across the world. Only 55% of the world's countries have effective 'multi-hazard early warning system' capable of responding comprehensively to extreme events.

articles.title: Hong Kong Asia Typhoon
articles.author: Beaumont Enterprise
articles.summary: Super Typhoon Ragasa approaches Hong Kong on Tuesday, Sept. 23, 2025. A pedestrian takes pictures at the waterfront of Victoria Harbor ahead of the typhoon, which is expected to make landfall in Hong Kong in the morning of September 23, 25th 2025.

articles.title: 5.5 million birds expected to fly over Oregon on Monday night. Here's how to help them
articles.author: The Oregonian
articles.summary: 5.5 million birds are expected to fly over Oregon tonight on their annual migration south. Sean Sterling is a social media producer at iReporter.com. He shares some tips on how to save a feathered friend tonight.   iReport.com:

articles.title: Humans Extend Global Wildfire Season by Over Month
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Human activity has added an average of 40 days to the global wildfire season. More than half of all burned area now happens outside the natural fire season. The transformation is most dramatic in tropical grasslands, where people have effectively extended the wildfire season by around three months. Even remote boreal forests and tundra are beginning to experience longer fire seasons. The study is expected to influence wildfire management strategies.

articles.title: Massive downpour turns Ischia streets into rivers
articles.author: ANSA English Desk
articles.summary: A huge downpour turned streets on the Gulf of Naples island of Ischia into rivers on Tuesday. Emergency services resumed the searches for a woman, a foreign tourist, reported missing at Spigno Monferrato, near Alessandria, on Monday after torrential rain battered a campsite. Scientists say the climate crisis caused by human greenhouse gas emissions is making extreme weather events more frequent and intense.

articles.title: China's Guangdong braces for super Typhoon Ragasa, shuts cities, flights and transport
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: Typhoon Ragasa is forecast to make landfall along the coastal areas from Zhuhai City to Xuwen County on Wednesday. More than 10 cities in Guangdong province have announced the closure of all markets, schools, factories and transport systems. Shenzhen's airport and the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge have been closed since Monday. Guangzhou cancelled all flights until Wednesday evening, and Zhuha cancelled 21 flights on Tuesday.

articles.title: Heat waves in rivers increase four times faster than atmospheric heat waves
articles.author: Miguel Ángel Criado
articles.summary: A study using data from over 1,000 rivers in the United States shows that extreme heat waves now last almost twice as long on the water as they do in the air. Since 1980, the number of days exceeding the threshold for critical thermal stress in 74% of rivers has increased by an average of 11.6°C. The study's authors link dams, which lengthen the duration of thermal extremes, with the increase of heat waves.

articles.title: 9 places on Earth where the sun never sets — the longest days in the world
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The midnight sun phenomenon occurs in latitudes above the Arctic Circle and below the Antarctic Circle during summer. The sun never sets for weeks or months in these latitudes. The cycle of day and night governs life on Earth, but in some regions the sun remains visible for a period longer than usual.

articles.title: Reviving The Serengeti: How Maasai Women's Dairy Initiatives Protect Wildlife And Communities
articles.author: Scoop
articles.summary: Maasai women are leading in the fight against habitat loss, climate change and shifting livelihoods. They are concerned about the future of their livelihoods and their environment.      Â   in the Maasai people are concerned with climate change.

articles.title: Survey: Augusta Chronicle asks for readers input on how best to cover climate change
articles.author: The Augusta Chronicle
articles.summary: Saturday marks the first anniversary of Hurricane Helene. Climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of natural disasters like hurricanes and severe flooding, according to a study published in Environmental Research: Climate, which suggests that climate change has increased.    .

articles.title: Spain among hardest hit as extreme heat killed over 62,000 people across Europe last year, study reveals - Olive Press News Spain
articles.author: Ben Pawlowski
articles.summary: There were 62,775 heat-related deaths across Europe last year between June 1 and September 30 due to a record-breaking heatwave. Spain recorded the second highest death toll with 6,743 deaths, with Italy taking the prize with over 19,000 deaths. Europe is warming at twice the global average.

articles.title: El Niño and La Niña in India: Causes, Climate Effects, and Weather Implications
articles.author: Anjali Rawat
articles.summary: El Niño warms Pacific, weakens Indian monsoon causing drought risk and extreme rains. La Niña cools Pacific, strengthens monsoon delivering higher rainfall and potential floods. India's relationship with ENSO events is critical due to heavy dependence on monsoon rainfall for agriculture and water resources.

articles.title: Helene by the numbers: A year after the storm, here's the data on Western NC's recovery
articles.author: Iris Seaton
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Helene ravaged Western North Carolina a year ago. The community is reflecting on the progress made since the storm and the progress that has been made so far. It's been a year since Helene made landfall in North Carolina and devastated the area.

articles.title: Canada vowed to curb fossil fuel production, but it and other major polluting countries have done the opposite, report suggests
articles.author: Metroland Staff
articles.summary: Canada and other fossil fuel-producing countries are ignoring the goals of the Paris Agreement signed a decade ago to reduce fossil fuel production. The Stockholm Environment Institute's Production Gap Report 2025 shows that the major fossil fuel producers are increasing their production levels instead of reducing it.

articles.title: Canada vowed to curb fossil fuel production, but it and other major polluting countries have done the opposite, report suggests
articles.author: Metroland Staff
articles.summary: The world's 20 major fossil-fuel-producing countries are increasing their fossil fuel production levels despite signing the Paris Agreement vowing to lower them. Niagara Region's weather, highway closures and top stories on Sept. 23 are listed below.

articles.title: Puerto Rico's climate revolution: Taking power back from the grid
articles.author: Kiara Alfonseca
articles.summary: In Adjuntas, Puerto Rico, a self-sustaining community is no longer waiting for government officials to offer protection during the hurricane season. The model of dependency upon FEMA and the government is degenerating. Climate challenges are increasing the risk of potential consequences.

articles.title: Madrac Farms prepares to open for first weekend of the season
articles.author: Mackenzie Baker
articles.summary: Madrac Farms in Effingham County is preparing for its first weekend of the season. The owners spent $3,000 on sprinklers and timers to get the corn to where it is now. The pumpkins they plant at the farm flourish in both dry and wet conditions. The farm opens on Saturday and will be open every weekend in October.

articles.title: How climate conference could throw Adelaide into chaos
articles.summary: COP 31 climate conference could cause gridlock on Adelaide's roads and streets next year. South Australia is seeking to hold the conference next year, but it could leave the roads in gridlock for Adelaide's residents and commuters.   Â

articles.title: Aircraft debate rages ahead of summer bushfire threat
articles.author: Jacob Shteyman
articles.summary: The disaster preparedness chief has dismissed calls for the Commonwealth to purchase its own fleet of firefighting aircraft. He insists the nation is prepared for the coming summer and is not in need of any new aircraft.       "The Commonwealth does not need to buy its own aircraft."

articles.title: Cholera shadow on Pakistan after devastating flood
articles.author: Yumna Asif
articles.summary: Flooding and landslides have affected more than 6 million people in Pakistan since late June. More than 1,000 people have died, 12,500 homes have been destroyed and 2 million people displaced. Health experts warn of an impending health emergency, including the threat of a cholera outbreak if urgent action is not taken. Climate change is being cited as a major contributor to Pakistan's worsening environmental disasters.

articles.title: Survey: Augusta Chronicle asks for readers input on how best to cover climate change
articles.author: Erica Van Buren
articles.summary: Saturday, Sept. 27 marks the first anniversary of Hurricane Helene. Climate change is impacting the frequency and intensity of natural disasters like hurricanes and severe flooding. Ocean temperatures made higher by human-caused climate change are fueling more intense hurricanes in the Atlantic. The Augusta Chronicle wants to know your thoughts on climate change and how we can best report on the issues in locally relevant ways.

articles.title: Bulgaria ranks second in Europe in heat-related deaths
articles.author: Maria Atanasova
articles.summary: Europe experienced an exceptionally deadly summer in 2024, with over 60,000 heat-related deaths. Greece has the highest mortality rate - 574 deaths per million people, followed by Bulgaria and Serbia. Italy is in first place with 19,000 deaths, Spain and Germany with over 6,000. Europe warming twice as fast as the global average.

articles.title: Climate Change Imperils N. Australia's Food Bowl Plans
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The first National Climate Risk Assessment was released last week. Northern Australia will be worst affected by climate change. Big plans are afoot to turn Northern Australia into Asia's "food bowl" as part of broader development for the region. Global warming will force natural, social and economic systems into uncharted climate territory.

articles.title: La Niña is coming: What it could mean for downstate New York this winter
articles.author: Brandi D. Addison
articles.summary: The Climate Prediction Center is calling for a warmer-than-normal, more mild fall across New York. The return of La Niña could complicate the outlook for winter, however.    .   in the fall.  in this year. in the previous year.

articles.title: Why Men Dominate BBQ Despite Women Cooking More
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: As the weather starts to warm, people will take to the great outdoors to enjoy BBQs. Traditional masculinity has a stronghold on BBQ. It is largely framed as an activity for men. Women do most of the cooking today and spend most of their time hunting and gathering.

articles.title: Wind farm threat to Fife fishermen is ‘hidden scandal of our time', says former minister
articles.author: The Courier
articles.summary: Fife fishermen say offshore wind farms threaten their livelihoods and call for compensation. MSPs are calling for fairer policies to protect their rights.       .   in the Scottish Parliament, the Scottish National Party is calling for a fairer policy to protect fishermen's rights.

articles.title: Take a look back at 10 years of monster fish at Tinaroo
articles.summary: After nearly 7500 roadside breath tests in the past six weeks, police reveal the 'scourge' risking lives on FNQ roads. Cairns' record-breaking wet September will give way to warmer temperatures for the rest of the month, with some Far Northern regions expecting temperatures five degrees above average.

articles.title: Countries planning to go past fossil fuel production goals: Report
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Countries are planning to produce more than double the amount of fossil fuels in 2030 than what would be consistent with limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. The Paris Agreement, under which countries committed to pursue efforts to limit warming to below 2 degrees, completes 10 years in 2025.

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat during 2024 summer: study
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: More than 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer. Europe is heating up twice as fast as the global average. Italy was the country with the most heat deaths last summer with an estimated 19,000, followed by Spain and Germany with over 6,000. Greece had the highest rate of heat deaths per million people.

articles.title: National Weather Forecast: Dry And Sunny For Most
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: It's Wednesday, the 24th of September. There's a strong high pressure system in the Great Australian Bight that extends a ridge across southern Australia, bringing generally settled and dry weather with clear skies and a lot of sunshine for the majority of the country. Out in the west, we've got heat building with daytime temperatures between 6 to 12 degrees above the September average. For Tasmania, another cold front will bring a burst of strong and gusty winds and enhancing shower activity. In Queensland, it's a generally dry and mostly sunny day with some morning frost patches possible about the Granite Belt and isolated showers about the exposed coasts. In Victoria, we're expecting morning frost and fog

articles.title: When the sun becomes a threat
articles.summary: Last year, the heat was too much for Hawawu Abdul Karim, a journalist in her mid-30s, who was working with Voice of America (Hausa) from Ghana. Africa is warming at 0.3°C per decade. Urban heat islands are intensifying in megacities like Lagos and Johannesburg. The world wants everyone to have clean energy by the year 2030.

articles.title: Warm sea 'hot spots' help hurricanes grow larger and more dangerous
articles.summary: Hurricanes grow bigger and quicker under certain ocean conditions. Last year's Hurricane Helene expanded substantially before it reached land, becoming the third-deadliest hurricane of the modern era. Researchers found a connection between storm growth and ocean "hot spots", or localised areas where the water is warmer. The study found that hurricane growth rates didn't change much with overall global warming.

articles.title: Nature fixes 'futile' if government keeps enabling harm
articles.author: Jack Gramenz
articles.summary: Australia's efforts to tackle climate change and fix environmental issues have been branded futile so long as repair programs are dwarfed by actions taking a sledgehammer to nature, as is the case with Australia's environmental repair programs.       .

articles.title: A storm is coming
articles.author: World Central Kitchen
articles.summary: Last year was the sixth in a row to show an erratic cycle and the third where all glacier regions reported ice loss. 60 per cent of rivers globally showed either too much or too little water compared to the average flow per year. Europe, central Africa, India and China saw wetter-than-average weather and some significant flooding events. Southern Africa and South America experienced dry conditions, including persistent drought.

articles.title: Kolkata Hit by Torrential Rains: 5 Reported Dead, Streets Flooded, Metro & Train Services Disrupted
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Kolkata and nearby regions experienced heavy overnight rainfall on Tuesday, resulting in flooding with knee-deep water covering roads and homes. At least five people have died in rain-related incidents including electrocution. The most intense rainfall was recorded in southern and eastern Kolkata, with Garia Kamdahari receiving 332 mm, followed by Jodhpur Park at 285 mm and Kalighat at 280 mm. Metro train services between Shahid Khudiram and Maidan stations on the Blue Line were suspended for safety due to waterlogging.

articles.title: Arup champions integrated climate action at Bangkok Climate Action Week 2025 to empower Southeast Asia's green transition
articles.author: Media Outreach
articles.summary: Arup is proud to participate in the inaugural Bangkok Climate Action Week (BKKCAW), a landmark city-wide climate festival that brings together all sectors of society to work towards a resilient and sustainable future in Southeast Asia. Media OutReach Newswire, 23 September 2025.

articles.title: Tamil Nadu's Mangrove Mission: A Green Triumph
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Tamil Nadu's commitment to expanding its mangrove ecosystem has borne fruit, with the forested area doubling from 4,500 to 9,039 hectares in just three years. The initiative includes the newly lush Adyar Estuary in Chennai. This transformation is part of a wider effort across nine coastal districts to create bio-shields against natural disasters like cyclones.

articles.title: Trifecta of rainy, hot, dry weather could be pattern of the future
articles.author: Tawnya Panizzi
articles.summary: This year's spring and summer weather pattern tracks with that of the past decade. The 30-year average for rain in March, April and May is 10.3 inches. In the past 10 years, the area has seen a wetter-than-usual spring with an average of 11 inches. This year, along with 2016 and 2024, was one of the warmest summers of the last decade.

articles.title: The Dry director heads to Antarctica for Nikki Gemmell film adaptation
articles.author: Garry Maddox
articles.summary: Robert Connolly is going to Antarctica to make a romantic drama based on Nikki Gemmell's novel Shiver. He will spend a month shooting the film on a ship and in the Antarctic near the Ross Sea early next year. Screen Australia has funded the project.

articles.title: Gambia: Saltwater Intrusion - Rising Seas Threaten Families and Farmland in Rural Gambia
articles.author: Nelson Manneh
articles.summary: There is a saltwater intrusion that threatens livelihoods and food security of farmers in Foni Kansala District. The intrusion of saline water has transformed once-productive rice paddies into nearly barren plots. Mariama Sanyang has seen half of the rice-growing land disappear beneath the rising tide. In Foni Jarol, the women's control over their land is slipping.

articles.title: Hong Kong braces for Super Typhoon Ragasa
articles.author: Farah Master
articles.summary: It warned of rising sea levels similar to those seen during Typhoon Hato in 2017 and Typhoon Mangkhut in 2018, both of which caused billions of dollars in damage. It said it would be similar to the ones seen during those two typhoons.

articles.title: Fossil fuels production in 2030 likely to be more than double of what is needed for 1.5 degree target: Report
articles.author: Amitabh Sinha
articles.summary: The Production Gap Report shows how the Paris Agreement climate goal is slipping out of hand. Fossil fuels contribute about 75% of global greenhouse gas emissions every year. The US withdrawal from Paris Agreement this January and the disappointing output from last year's annual climate conference in Baku, Azerbaijan have seen the momentum on climate action getting eroded. The special high-level event is being organised by UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres on the sidelines of UN General Assembly session.

articles.title: I'm a dermatologist - don't bother wearing sunscreen in winter
articles.author: Sadhbh O'Sullivan
articles.summary: Summer is over and it's getting colder, so people are thinking about wearing sunscreen in autumn and winter. YouGov survey found 53% of 18-24-year-olds agree SPF should be worn all year round, but Professor Brian Diffey, a photobiologist, says it's not necessary. He says it won't reduce wrinkles and it could compromise your vitamin D intake.

articles.title: Why days are getting a little brighter across Australia
articles.author: Patrick Brischetto2:36pm
articles.summary: Today marks the 2025 spring equinox in Australia and the Southern Hemisphere. Days will be longer than nights for the next six months. Nights will remain shorter than days until the next equilux in March next year. Winter will hit Australia as winter solstice is in December.

articles.title: 'Global Warming: Apocalypse or Hot Air?' presents a contrarian view of the climate debate
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: 'Global Warming: Apocalypse or Hot Air?' presents a contrarian view of the climate debate. Roger Bate and Julian Morris acknowledge the natural greenhouse effect, but challenge the notion of a significant "enhanced greenhouse effect" due to human activities. They argue that climate models have consistently overestimated temperature increases and fail to accurately predict current temperatures, casting doubt on their reliability for future projections. They advocate for the elimination of government intervention in the energy market, believing that free markets are better at allocating resources and adapting to environmental changes.

articles.title: Fire Ban Alert: Darwin, Adelaide River, Barkly Regions
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The fire ban is valid from midnight on Wednesday 24 September 2025 for the following fire weather forecast areas: Darwin and Adelaide River, including Darwin, Palmerston, Litchfield and Coomalie. Barkly North, including Elliott, Newcastle Waters, Barkly Homestead and Ranken, and Barkly South, including Tennant Creek, Threeways and Ali Curung.

articles.title: Hong Kong braces for Super Typhoon Ragasa with schools, businesses shut
articles.author: Farah Master
articles.summary: Ragasa hit the Philippines on Monday, prompting President Ferdinand Marcos Jnr to order the disaster response agency to go on full alert and mobilise all government agencies. The Hong Kong Observatory warns of a significant storm and sea surge in Hong Kong on Wednesday. Water levels will rise about 2m along Hong Kong's coastal areas and maximum water levels could reach up to 4m to 5m in some areas. Chinese authorities have activated flood control measures in several southern provinces, warning of heavy rain from late on Tuesday. In China's technology hub Shenzhen, authorities have prepared more than 800 emergency shelters.

articles.title: China closes schools, cancels flights as it braces for Ragasa, one of the strongest typhoons in years

The typhoon is expected to make landfall in the coastal area between Shenzhen city and Xuwen county in Guangdong province on Wednesday (September 24, 2025). The observatory in Hong Kong will issue storm warning signal No. 8 on Tuesday afternoon.

articles.title: Pakistan's Deluge: Impact on Economy and Agriculture
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Flooding in Punjab and Sindh provinces threatens Pakistan's economic recovery post-IMF bailout. Farmers report catastrophic crop losses. Estimates suggest vast swathes of rice, cotton, and maize have been destroyed. Industrial hubs, vital for exports, are also heavily affected.

articles.title: Latest science further exposes lies about rising seas
articles.author: Vijay Jayaraj
articles.summary: A new study confirms that sea levels are rising, but the rate of rise has not accelerated. The current period of gradual sea-level rise began between 1800-1860, before any significant CO2 emissions. The study suggests that projections by the IPCC overestimate the annual rise by 2 millimeters per year by 2100.

articles.title: Pakistan's Flood Crisis: A Nation Under Water
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Floods in Pakistan have ravaged rural landscapes and key industrial zones for the first time in decades, causing billions of dollars in damages and exacerbating existing strains on food supplies, exports, and the country's fragile economic revival. Punjab, a major agricultural hub for rice, cotton, and maize, witnessed 1.8 million acres of farmland submerged. Experts warn that this disaster may lead to increased food insecurity.

articles.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa Sparks Chaos Across Southern China and the Philippines
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Typhoon Ragasa has devastated Southern China and the Philippines. At least three people have died in Taiwan and thousands have been displaced in the Philippines due to the storm. articles.title: Authorities prepare for worst-case scenarios ahead of typhoon Ragasa

articles.summary: Typhoon Ragasa entered the East Sea on the night of September 22, officially becoming typhoon No. 9. The National Civil Defense Steering Committee held an emergency working session to debate response measures for the approaching super typhoon. Border forces accounted for and notified 54,058 vessels carrying 215,743 personnel at sea about the approaching storm. Provinces from Quang Ninh to Hue have 161,354 hectares of aquaculture, 31,812 fish cages and 3,875 guard huts in need of protection. The Ministry of Agriculture and Environment reported that nearly 146,000 hectares of rice are ripe.

articles.title: Environment fixes 'futile' as long as harms approved

articles.summary: Australia's efforts to tackle climate change and fix environmental issues have been branded futile because less money is spent on programs to restore nature than on those supporting its destruction.    .      in Australia's efforts, less money spent on restoration than on destroying nature.

articles.summary: Hurricane Helene damaged a Greenville home a year ago. Will Crooks shows the difference a year makes between a hurricane and a hurricane a year later. He also shows the damage that Hurricane Helene caused to a house in Greenville, a city in which he lives.

articles.title: The science says fossil fuel exports must peak this year: What will Australia do about that?
articles.author: Renew Economy
articles.summary: We cannot let 'achievability' become the new smokescreen delaying crucial climate action, as it has happened in the past, as we have seen in the case of the UNFCCC. We need to focus on the real issues at hand and not on 'achieveability'.

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat last year

articles.summary: 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer. Europe experienced an exceptionally deadly summer in 2024 with more than 60,000 heat-related deaths, bringing the total burden over the past three summers to more than 181,000.

articles.author: Faras Ghani

articles.summary: The bridge on East Butler Road over I-385 in Greenville County will be closed in 2026 for repairs. Comments regarding the repairs will be accepted through October 21.

articles.title: 8 Swedish glaciers disappeared
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Eight of Sweden's 277 glaciers melted completely during 2024 and are now extinct due to global warming. Another 30 glaciers are at risk. Cunujokeln in the Vadvetjakka national park was the biggest of the eight, about the size of six football pitches.

articles.title: Johnson County Officials Reflect on Hurricane Helene's Effects and Recovery Efforts, One Year Later
articles.author: Internewscast

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat last year

Italy was the country with the most heat deaths last summer with an estimated 19,000, followed by Spain and Germany with over 6,000. Greece had the highest rate with 574 deaths per million people.

articles.title: Women in the centre
articles.author: Munazza Khan
articles.summary: Pakistan is experiencing a catastrophic flood crisis. The most severe impact of this climate disaster is being experienced by women, especially in rural and low-income societies. According to the UN Population Fund, of the populations affected by floods, 1.6 million women of reproductive age are found with almost 130,000 pregnant women among them and most in need of urgent medical care. The National Climate Change Policy of Pakistan recognises the vulnerability of women, yet practicality is poor. Gender-specific needs are not always taken into account in disaster management plans and women are not well represented in making decisions.

articles.title: When Institutions Listen
articles.summary: SPSC postponed the CCE-2024 Screening Test due to reliable forecasts of consecutive rain spells. Canada and Australia recognise Palestinian statehood. Inflation erodes wealth, while debt grows like a shadow. Israel's aggression spills beyond Palestine's borders with impunity.

articles.title: Climate intervention: A responsible way to cool the planet
articles.author: Zeke Hausfather
articles.summary: Since the Industrial Revolution, burning coal and oil has filled the air with sulfur, shortening the lives of billions of people. Global sulfur emissions have fallen 40% since 2006. China has slashed them by about 70%. By reflecting sunlight back into space, sulfur particles protected Earth from about a third of the warming caused by human emissions of carbon dioxide. Global leaders gather in New York for UN General Assembly and Climate Week.

articles.title: Climate change: Lagos Island, Apapa communities confront rising tide
articles.author: Sola Ogundipe
articles.summary: Lagos Island and Apapa are two coastal areas vulnerable to flooding and sea-level rise due to climate change. A new pilot project, led by the Lagos State Civil Society Participation for Development (LACSOP) with support from Bread for the World (BfdW), mobilises youth and community stakeholders to confront environmental challenges. A validation workshop was held in Lagos to validate a draft manual on climate change adaptation. The training manual is designed to equip youths with the knowledge and tools to mitigate climate impacts.

articles.title: Academy Urges: Meet Challenge, Maintain Targets
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The National Climate Risk Assessment has reinforced the urgency for Australia and the world to accelerate investment in our path to net-zero emissions. The Academy's 2023 report on greenhouse gas removal highlighted how current removal and storage technologies are not yet at the scale needed to make the difference we need now. Emissions reduction or removal technology either does not exist or is too expensive, so investment in research and science capability must be prioritised and scaled up.

articles.title: Australian states that still think it's winter
articles.author: George Al-Akiki
articles.summary: Some parts of Victoria and South Australia have been hit with frost warnings this week. The cold snap has been driven by a strong high-pressure system in The Bight. Sydney is set to feel the heat later in the week, reaching a top of 30C by Saturday, while Brisbane will soar up to 31C.

articles.title: Preparedness Ramps Up for High-Risk Weather Season
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Bureau of Meteorology releases its Higher Risk Weather Season Outlook. There is an increased risk of bushfire during spring in parts of Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria. The official summer 2025-26 bushfire outlook will be issued in November. The Albanese Government is working with states and territories to improve disaster management arrangements so there is a strategic shift towards disaster risk reduction.

Greece had the highest death rate in 2024, followed by Bulgaria and Serbia. Mediterranean and Southeast regions are most affected. Women and the elderly are the most vulnerable groups.

articles.author: NBC Bay Area
articles.summary: U.S. rivers are running hot. The frequency, intensity and duration of heat waves is increasing in streams across the country. It poses a threat to many species that are adapted to cooler temperatures. The trend is increasing faster than the air heat waves, which is surprising.
